title: Eating behaviours: tracking through the lifecourse and impact on chronic disease.
abstractText: Many believe that our modern lifestyle, and eating small amounts more often, may be contributing to recent increases in obesity, along with skipping breakfast, and eating later in the evening and at night. We shall use the dietary records of individuals studied for long periods of time, and whose weight, blood pressure and other risk factors for disease have been measured to assess whether how and when food is eaten, and whether or not changing the pattern of eating relates to obesity and other health measures, so that appropriate healthy eating messages are given to the public.
